Tl g HE

Historical Background

.

pressway. Eastbound traffic on the East-West Expressway desiring to go
north on the Jones Falls Expressway would follow the reverse path. No
new construction would be necessary north of Cathedral Street (except
that additional traffic on Mt. Royal Terrace between Cathedral Street and
North Avenue might require a widening of the paved area through a
reduction of the median strip) but Cathedral Street would be widened
to the west by taking the property now occupied by the Deutsches House
as well as some land now being cleared as part of the Mt. Royal Plaza.
In addition, a few other properties would be acquired in order to effect the
necessary connection between Cathedral Street and the East-West Ex-
pressway. Cathedral Street would terminate at this connection. Surface
traffic desiring to go further south would be handled by Maryland Avenue.

This proposal does not meet Federal Interstate Highway Standards
and would not therefore be eligible for 90% Federal subsidy. (It would
probably be eligible for 509 Federal subsidy under the so-called Urban
Program.) With respect to the interchange between the Jones Falls
Expressway and the East-West Expressway there would be no reduction
in property takings in the Mt. Vernon area. The proposal does permit a
simplified interchange to be designed as shown on Sheet 20.

Officials of the State Roads Commission indicated that it would be
acceptable to them for the City to use this simplified intersection plan as a
basis for proceeding with the Jones Falls Expressway and Mr. George
Carter, then Director of Public Works, instructed the design engineers to
go ahead accordingly. He informed them, however, to incorporate in their
plans only those provisions for the interchange which were absolutely
essential so that if the East-West Expressway were never built, or if it
were built in some other location, no unsightly stubs for ramps would be
left dangling into space.

13

All the events described above from the beginning of 1958 took place
as a result of efforts to get on with the design of the Jones Falls Express-
way. Nevertheless this required that considerable attention be devoted
to the East-West Expressway and the resulting public controversy led
Mayor D’Alesandro in September of 1958 to request the Department of
Planning and the Planning Commission to make a further study of the
Expressway route. The Mayor concluded his request by asking “. . ..
that due consideration be given to the preservation of neighborhoods and
the development of needed facilities for moving people, particularly the
people of the Baltimore metropolitan area.” This report is the result of
this request.

o
